definition: The process of making an application or module available for use.
example: The deployment to the production environment is scheduled for Friday night.

definition: A nearly exact replica of a production environment for software testing.
example: We test all features in staging before they go live.

definition: The process of keeping a software system operational and updating it.
example: The server will be down for scheduled maintenance at midnight.

definition: A period of time when a system is unavailable.
example: Unplanned downtime costs the company thousands of dollars per hour.

definition: The time during which a machine or system is in operation.
example: Our goal is to maintain ninety-nine percent uptime this year.

definition: A small piece of code developed to correct a major bug in a software product.
example: Developers released a hotfix to patch the security vulnerability.

definition: A set of changes to a computer program or its supporting data designed to update, fix, or improve it.
example: Make sure to apply the latest security patch to the operating system.

definition: A document describing a software error and how to reproduce it.
example: Please attach screenshots to the bug report to help us understand the issue.

definition: A suggestion from a user or team member for a new capability in the software.
example: We received a feature request to add dark mode to the application.

definition: A list of tasks required to support a larger strategic plan.
example: The team prioritized items in the backlog for the next sprint.

definition: The process of identifying all the work that needs to be done in a project.
example: Poor scope definition often leads to project delays later on.

definition: A significant point or event in a project timeline.
example: Releasing the beta version was a major milestone for the startup.

definition: A tangible or intangible good or service produced as a result of a project.
example: The main deliverable for this phase is the functional specification document.

definition: The latest time or date by which something should be completed.
example: We need to work overtime to meet the tight deadline.

definition: A person with an interest or concern in the success of a project.
example: We present the weekly progress report to the key stakeholders.

definition: A condition or capability that must be met or possessed by a system.
example: The client added a new requirement regarding data privacy.

definition: A detailed description of the design and materials used to make something.
example: The developer followed the technical specification to build the API.

definition: A strategic plan that defines a goal or desired outcome and includes the major steps or milestones needed to reach it.
example: The product roadmap shows that mobile support will be added in Q3.

definition: The process of finding an approximation, which is a value that is usable for some purpose.
example: Our estimation for this task was too optimistic.

definition: The fact or condition of being regarded or treated as more important.
example: Fixing critical bugs takes priority over adding new features.

definition: A point of congestion in a system that slows down the overall process.
example: The manual testing phase became a bottleneck in the release cycle.

definition: An issue or bug that prevents testing or development from proceeding.
example: We cannot continue with the deployment until the database blocker is resolved.

definition: The sequence of processes through which a piece of work passes from initiation to completion.
example: We automated the approval workflow to save time.

definition: Uncontrolled changes or continuous growth in a project's scope.
example: Scope creep caused the project to go over budget and miss the deadline.

definition: A design goal where components interact with each other with minimal dependencies.
example: Loose coupling allows us to update the payment service without breaking the checkout process.

definition: The ability of computer systems or software to exchange and make use of information.
example: Ensuring interoperability between different healthcare systems is a major challenge.

definition: Status of a feature that is tolerated but discouraged because it has been superseded.
example: This function is deprecated and will be removed in the next version.

definition: Source code that relates to a no-longer supported or manufactured operating system or other computer technology.
example: Refactoring legacy code is difficult because it lacks documentation.

definition: The process of restructuring existing computer code without changing its external behavior.
example: We spent a week refactoring the code to make it more readable.

definition: The action of making the best or most effective use of a situation or resource.
example: Database optimization reduced query time by half.

definition: The amount of material or items passing through a system or process.
example: We increased the system throughput to handle more transactions per second.

definition: The capacity to be changed in size or scale.
example: The cloud architecture provides infinite scalability for our web app.

definition: The inclusion of extra components which are not strictly necessary to functioning, in case of failure in other components.
example: Redundancy in data storage protects us from hardware failure.

definition: A copy of a file or other item of data made in case the original is lost or damaged.
example: Always perform a backup before updating the server software.

definition: To bring back or re-establish a previous state.
example: It took two hours to restore the database from the last backup.

definition: The structure of a database system, described in a formal language.
example: Changing the database schema requires a migration script.

definition: A request for information from a database.
example: The search query returned zero results.

definition: A method to optimize the performance of a database by minimizing the number of disk accesses.
example: Proper indexing significantly speeds up data retrieval.

definition: The process of converting information or data into a code, especially to prevent unauthorized access.
example: End-to-end encryption ensures only the sender and receiver can read the message.

definition: The process of converting encrypted data back into its original form.
example: The software handles the decryption of files automatically upon login.

definition: The process or action of verifying the identity of a user or process.
example: Two-factor authentication adds an extra layer of security.

definition: The function of specifying access rights/privileges to resources.
example: Authentication verifies who you are, while authorization determines what you can do.

definition: A weakness which allows an attacker to reduce a system's information assurance.
example: Regular scans help detect any new security vulnerability.

definition: An incident where data is inadvertently exposed or stolen.
example: The company notified customers about the data breach immediately.

definition: An automated process of negotiation between two entities to set parameters of communication.
example: The SSL handshake failed because of a certificate mismatch.

definition: A point where two systems, subjects, organizations, etc., meet and interact.
example: The user interface should be intuitive and easy to navigate.

definition: A data item that may take on more than one value during the runtime of a program.
example: Define a global variable to store the user's settings.

definition: A numerical or other measurable factor forming one of a set that defines a system or sets the conditions of its operation.
example: You need to pass the correct parameter to the function.

definition: The set of rules that defines the combinations of symbols that are considered to be a correctly structured document or fragment in that language.
example: A missing semicolon caused a syntax error in the code.

definition: A process or set of rules to be followed in calculations or other problem-solving operations.
example: We improved the sorting algorithm to handle larger lists.

definition: To identify and remove errors from computer hardware or software.
example: I spent hours trying to debug the crash issue.

definition: A program that converts instructions into a machine-code or lower-level form so that they can be read and executed by a computer.
example: The compiler checks for errors before creating the executable file.

definition: A software component that another piece of software relies on to function.
example: We use a package manager to handle project dependencies.

definition: A central location in which data is stored and managed.
example: Push your changes to the remote repository every day.

definition: A parallel version of a repository.
example: Create a new branch for the feature you are working on.

definition: To combine distinct changes from one version branch into another.
example: After review, merge your branch into the main codebase.

definition: A situation where two branches have competing changes to the same line of a file.
example: You need to resolve the merge conflict before you can deploy.

definition: A method of submitting contributions to an open development project.
example: My pull request is waiting for approval from the team lead.

definition: To save changes to a repository.
example: Make sure to write a clear message when you commit your code.

definition: The delay before a transfer of data begins following an instruction for its transfer.
example: High latency makes video calls choppy and unreliable.

definition: The maximum amount of data that can be transmitted over an internet connection in a given amount of time.
example: We increased the server bandwidth to handle the traffic spike.

definition: A hardware or software component that stores data so that future requests for that data can be served faster.
example: The browser cache stores images to load web pages faster.

definition: A temporary period of interaction between two computing nodes.
example: The user session expires automatically after thirty minutes of inactivity.

definition: A small piece of data stored on the user's computer by the web browser.
example: We use a cookie to remember your language preference.

definition: A piece of data that acts as a proxy for a larger piece of data or a permission.
example: The API returns an access token upon successful login.

definition: One end of a communication channel.
example: You need to call the user profile endpoint to get the data.

definition: The time a system or functional unit takes to react to a given input.
example: Optimizing the code reduced the server response time significantly.

definition: The process of putting demand on a system and measuring its response.
example: Load testing revealed that the system crashes at ten thousand users.

definition: A software testing method by which individual units of source code are tested.
example: Write a unit test for every new function you create.

definition: A phase in software testing in which individual software modules are combined and tested as a group.
example: The integration test failed because the API format changed.

definition: A report of the active stack frames at a certain point in time during the execution of a program.
example: The stack trace helped us locate the exact line where the error occurred.

definition: An anomalous or exceptional condition requiring special processing.
example: The program threw an unhandled exception and closed unexpectedly.

definition: A record of events that occur within an operating system or other software.
example: Check the server log to see why the connection failed.

definition: The arrangement or set-up of the hardware and software that make up a computer system.
example: The incorrect network configuration prevented access to the database.

definition: The conditions under which a computer system works.
example: The bug only appears in the development environment, not production.

definition: A documented request for support or service in an issue tracking system.
example: Please open a support ticket if you cannot access your email.

definition: The process of moving an issue to a higher level of support or management.
example: The critical server outage required immediate escalation to the engineering team.

definition: Information, such as a username and password, used to verify identity.
example: Never share your login credential with anyone outside the IT department.

definition: Technology that allows a user to connect to a specific computer from a remote location.
example: Support technicians use remote desktop to troubleshoot issues on employee laptops.

definition: A temporary method for achieving a task or solving a problem when the usual method is not working.
example: We provided a workaround for the printing issue until the driver is updated.

definition: A centralized repository for information: a public library, a database of related information about a particular subject.
example: Check the internal knowledge base for instructions on setting up the VPN.

definition: The selective restriction of access to a place or other resource.
example: Strict access control ensures only authorized personnel can enter the server room.

definition: A security-relevant chronological record, set of records, and/or destination and source of records.
example: The audit trail showed exactly who modified the financial records.

definition: Software that is specifically designed to disrupt, damage, or gain unauthorized access to a computer system.
example: The antivirus software detected malware hidden in the email attachment.

definition: The fraudulent practice of sending emails purporting to be from reputable companies to induce individuals to reveal personal information.
example: The company conducts regular training to help employees recognize phishing attempts.

definition: The process of moving data or software from one system to another.
example: The database migration to the cloud took longer than expected.

definition: The property that ensures that a transaction brings the database from one valid state to another.
example: Data consistency is critical in banking applications.

definition: The maintenance of, and the assurance of the accuracy and consistency of, data over its entire life-cycle.
example: Foreign key constraints help maintain the referential integrity of the database.

definition: The process of copying data from a central database to one or more databases.
example: We use database replication to ensure high availability across regions.

definition: A record of the memory of a computer process, usually used for debugging.
example: The developer analyzed the memory dump to find the cause of the crash.

definition: The delay before a transfer of data begins following an instruction for its transfer.
example: Low latency is essential for a good user experience in online gaming.

definition: The maximum amount of data that can be transmitted over an internet connection in a given amount of time.
example: Video streaming consumes a significant amount of network bandwidth.

definition: A set of rules governing the exchange or transmission of data between devices.
example: The secure file transfer protocol is used to upload sensitive documents.

definition: A network security system that monitors and controls incoming and outgoing network traffic.
example: The corporate firewall blocks access to social media sites.

definition: A server application or appliance that acts as an intermediary for requests from clients seeking resources from servers.
example: We route all traffic through a proxy server for security inspection.

definition: A software application in which different components are combined into a single program from a single platform.
example: Breaking the monolith into microservices will improve deployment speed.

definition: An architectural style that structures an application as a collection of services.
example: The microservices architecture allows independent scaling of components.

definition: A characteristic of a system that aims to ensure an agreed level of operational performance, usually uptime, for a higher than normal period.
example: Our payment system is designed for high availability to prevent revenue loss.

definition: The property that enables a system to continue operating properly in the event of the failure of some of its components.
example: Fault tolerance mechanisms ensured the app kept running despite the disk error.

definition: The capability of a system, network, or process to handle a growing amount of work.
example: Horizontal scalability allows us to add more servers as traffic grows.

definition: A device that acts as a reverse proxy and distributes network or application traffic across a number of servers.
example: The load balancer ensures no single server is overwhelmed during peak hours.

definition: An isolated testing environment that enables users to run programs without affecting the application.
example: Malicious code executed in the sandbox cannot harm the host system.

definition: The automated configuration, coordination, and management of computer systems and software.
example: Container orchestration tools manage the lifecycle of thousands of containers.

definition: The practice of merging all developers' working copies to a shared mainline several times a day.
example: Continuous integration helps us detect integration errors early.

definition: A software engineering approach in which software functionalities are delivered frequently through automated deployments.
example: With continuous deployment, every passed test triggers a release to production.

definition: A program or sequence of instructions that is interpreted or carried out by another program.
example: I wrote a Python script to automate the data backup process.

definition: A user interface for access to an operating system's services.
example: System administrators use the shell to execute commands on the server.

definition: A central file storage location. It is used by version control systems to store multiple versions of files.
example: Clone the code repository to start working on the project.

definition: A piece of software that relies on another piece of software.
example: Updating the library broke a dependency in the billing module.

definition: Sections of code that have to be included in many places with little or no alteration.
example: We use a generator to reduce the amount of boilerplate code we need to write.

definition: A collection of non-volatile resources used by computer programs, often for software development.
example: The image processing library handles all the photo resizing tasks.

definition: A specific URL where an API can be accessed by a client application.
example: We need to secure the authentication endpoint to prevent brute-force attacks.

definition: A collection of software development tools in one installable package.
example: The payment provider's SDK made integration very simple.

definition: A software application that provides comprehensive facilities to computer programmers for software development.
example: Most developers prefer an IDE with strong debugging features.

definition: A process or set of rules to be followed in calculations or other problem-solving operations.
example: The search algorithm ranks results by relevance.

definition: The process of defining something in terms of itself.
example: Recursion is useful for traversing tree-like data structures.

definition: The repetition of a process in order to generate a (possibly unbounded) sequence of outcomes.
example: We improved the user interface in the second iteration of the design.

definition: The ability of different parts or units of a program, algorithm, or problem to be executed out-of-order or in partial order.
example: Concurrency allows the server to handle multiple requests at the same time.

definition: Events that are not coordinated in time.
example: Asynchronous processing prevents the user interface from freezing during data loading.

definition: Existing or occurring at the same time.
example: The synchronous call blocks the execution until a response is received.

definition: A hardware or software component that stores data so that future requests for that data can be served faster.
example: Clearing the browser cache resolves many display issues.

definition: A temporary interaction between two communication endpoints.
example: The user session expires after 30 minutes of inactivity.

definition: A small piece of data stored on the user's computer by the web browser.
example: The site uses a cookie to remember your login status.

definition: The process of converting information or data into a code, especially to prevent unauthorized access.
example: End-to-end encryption protects the privacy of user messages.

definition: The process of converting encrypted data back into its original form.
example: Only the holder of the private key can perform decryption of the file.

definition: The process or action of verifying the identity of a user or process.
example: Multi-factor authentication adds a layer of security to the login process.

definition: The function of specifying access rights/privileges to resources.
example: Authorization rules determine which reports a user can view.

definition: A thing serving as a visible or tangible representation of a fact, quality, feeling, etc.
example: The API requires a valid access token in the header.

definition: One end of a communication channel.
example: The API endpoint for user data is currently down.

definition: A numerical or other measurable factor forming one of a set that defines a system or sets the conditions of its operation.
example: Pass the user ID as a query parameter in the URL.

definition: A data item that may take on more than one value during the runtime of a program.
example: Initialize the counter variable to zero.

definition: A value that cannot be altered by the program during normal execution.
example: Define the tax rate as a constant since it rarely changes.

definition: The set of rules that defines the combinations of symbols that are considered to be a correctly structured document or fragment in that language.
example: A missing semicolon caused a syntax error in the code.

definition: The action or process of producing something, especially a list, book, or report, by assembling information collected from other sources.
example: The code compilation failed due to a missing library.

definition: The action of explaining the meaning of something.
example: Python uses interpretation to execute code line by line.

definition: A computer program used to test and debug other programs.
example: Use the debugger to step through the code and find the logic error.

definition: A record of events that occur within an operating system or other software.
example: Examine the server log to trace the source of the error.

definition: The action of notifying someone or something.
example: The system sends a notification when the task is complete.

definition: A warning or notification of a specific event.
example: The monitoring system triggered an alert when CPU usage hit 90%.

definition: A method of measuring something, or the results obtained from this.
example: Response time is a key metric for evaluating system performance.

definition: A user interface that organizes and presents information in a way that is easy to read.
example: The analytics dashboard shows real-time user activity.

definition: The overall experience of a person using a product such as a website or computer application.
example: Slow page loads negatively impact the user experience.

definition: The means by which the user and a computer system interact.
example: The new user interface is cleaner and more intuitive.

definition: The quality of being able to be reached or entered.
example: We improved accessibility by adding screen reader support.

definition: Reacting quickly and positively.
example: The responsive design adapts perfectly to mobile screens.

definition: An image or set of images which displays the functional elements of a website or page.
example: The designer created a wireframe to outline the page structure.

definition: A first, typical or preliminary model of something, especially a machine, from which other forms are developed or copied.
example: We built a clickable prototype to test the user flow.

definition: A model or replica of a machine or structure, used for instructional or experimental purposes.
example: The high-fidelity mockup shows exactly how the app will look.

definition: The degree to which something is able or fit to be used.
example: Usability testing helped us identify confusing navigation elements.

definition: A role or character adopted by an author or an actor.
example: We created a user persona to better understand our target audience.

definition: A property of certain operations in mathematics and computer science whereby they can be applied multiple times without changing the result beyond the initial application.
example: Designing the API for idempotency ensures that retrying a failed payment request doesn't charge the customer twice.

definition: The ability of different parts or units of a program, algorithm, or problem to be executed out-of-order or in partial order, without affecting the final outcome.
example: Handling concurrency correctly is crucial to prevent race conditions in multi-threaded applications.

definition: An undesirable situation that occurs when a device or system attempts to perform two or more operations at the same time, but because of the nature of the device or system, the operations must be done in the proper sequence to be done correctly.
example: A race condition occurred when two users tried to update the same record simultaneously.

definition: A situation in computing where two processes are each waiting for the other to release a resource, or more than two processes are waiting for resources in a circular chain.
example: The database transaction failed due to a deadlock between two competing queries.

definition: A consistency model used in distributed computing to achieve high availability that informally guarantees that, if no new updates are made to a given data item, eventually all accesses to that item will return the last updated value.
example: In a NoSQL database, we often accept eventual consistency in exchange for higher performance.

definition: A type of database partitioning that separates very large databases the into smaller, faster, more easily managed parts.
example: We implemented sharding to distribute the user data across multiple database servers.

definition: A design pattern used in software development to detect failures and encapsulate the logic of preventing a failure from constantly recurring.
example: The circuit breaker pattern stops the application from trying to connect to a failing service repeatedly.

definition: A technique in which an object receives other objects that it depends on.
example: Using dependency injection makes unit testing easier by allowing us to mock dependencies.

definition: The provision of a single interface to entities of different types or the use of a single symbol to represent multiple different types.
example: Polymorphism allows us to treat different shapes like circles and squares as a generic 'Shape' object.

definition: The bundling of data with the methods that operate on that data, or the restricting of direct access to some of an object's components.
example: Encapsulation protects the internal state of the object from being modified directly by external code.

definition: The process of removing physical, spatial, or temporal details or attributes in the study of objects or systems to focus attention on details of greater importance.
example: The API provides a high level of abstraction, hiding the complex logic happening in the background.

definition: The mechanism of basing an object or class upon another object or class, retaining similar implementation.
example: Through inheritance, the 'Car' class acquires all the properties of the 'Vehicle' class.

definition: The process of defining a problem (or the solution to a problem) in terms of (a simpler version of) itself.
example: The factorial function is a classic example of recursion in programming.

definition: A mathematical notation that describes the limiting behavior of a function when the argument tends towards a particular value or infinity.
example: We analyze the algorithm using Big O notation to understand its performance as the dataset grows.

definition: The process of translating a data structure or object state into a format that can be stored or transmitted and reconstructed later.
example: JSON serialization converts the user object into a string for API transmission.

definition: The process of converting serialized data back into a data structure or object.
example: Security vulnerabilities can occur during deserialization if the input is not validated.

definition: An approach to managing services and software deployments on IT resources wherein components are replaced rather than changed.
example: With immutable infrastructure, we destroy and recreate servers instead of patching them.

definition: The process of setting up IT infrastructure. It can also refer to the steps required to manage access to data and resources, and make them available to users and systems.
example: Automated provisioning scripts set up the new server environment in minutes.

definition: The act of creating a virtual (rather than actual) version of something, including virtual computer hardware platforms, storage devices, and computer network resources.
example: Hardware virtualization allows multiple operating systems to run on a single physical machine.

definition: A design pattern where a separate container runs alongside the main application container to provide supporting features.
example: We use the sidecar pattern to handle logging and monitoring for our microservices.

definition: A type of proxy server that retrieves resources on behalf of a client from one or more servers.
example: The reverse proxy handles SSL termination and load balancing for the backend servers.

definition: An automated process of negotiation between two entities (usually computers or modems) to set parameters for a communication channel.
example: The TLS handshake establishes a secure connection before any data is transferred.

definition: In computing, a measure of the randomness collected by an operating system or application for use in cryptography.
example: Low entropy can make cryptographic keys predictable and insecure.

definition: Random data that is used as an additional input to a one-way function that hashes data, a password or passphrase.
example: Always add a unique salt to each password before hashing it to prevent rainbow table attacks.

definition: The process of transforming any given key or a string of characters into another value.
example: Hashing is used to verify data integrity by comparing the calculated hash with the original.

definition: The process of cleaning input data to prevent security exploits.
example: Input sanitization is critical to prevent SQL injection attacks.

definition: A technique designed for solving a problem more quickly when classic methods are too slow, or for finding an approximate solution when classic methods fail to find any exact solution.
example: The antivirus uses heuristic analysis to detect new, unknown viruses based on behavior.

definition: The process of restructuring existing computer codechanging the factoringwithout changing its external behavior.
example: Refactoring the legacy codebase improved maintainability and readability.

definition: A concept in software development that reflects the implied cost of additional rework caused by choosing an easy (limited) solution now instead of using a better approach that would take longer.
example: We need to dedicate a sprint to paying down technical debt before adding more features.

definition: The automated configuration, coordination, and management of computer systems and software.
example: Kubernetes provides orchestration for deploying and managing containerized applications.

definition: The process of organizing data in a database. This includes creating tables and establishing relationships between those tables according to rules designed both to protect the data and to make the database more flexible by eliminating redundancy and inconsistent dependency.
example: Database normalization reduces data redundancy but can make queries more complex.

definition: The process of trying to improve the read performance of a database, at the expense of losing some write performance, by adding redundant copies of data or by grouping data.
example: We used denormalization to speed up the reporting queries.

definition: A set of properties of database transactions intended to guarantee data validity despite errors, power failures, and other mishaps.
example: Relational databases prioritize ACID compliance to ensure reliable transactions.

definition: A theorem stating that it is impossible for a distributed data store to simultaneously provide more than two out of the following three guarantees: Consistency, Availability, and Partition tolerance.
example: According to the CAP theorem, we must choose between consistency and availability during a network partition.

definition: The rate of production or the rate at which something can be processed.
example: Optimizing the I/O operations increased the system's throughput by 20%.

definition: The time interval between the stimulation and response, or, from a more general point of view, a time delay between the cause and the effect of some physical change in the system being observed.
example: Network latency can significantly impact the performance of real-time applications.

definition: The property that enables a system to continue operating properly in the event of the failure of (or one or more faults within) some of its components.
example: Building fault tolerance into the system ensures it stays up even if a server crashes.

definition: A method by which one party (the prover) can prove to another party (the verifier) that they know a value x, without conveying any information apart from the fact that they know the value x.
example: Zero-knowledge proofs allow authentication without transmitting the actual password.

definition: Ideally checking the status of an external device or system repeatedly to see if it's ready.
example: Polling the API every second is inefficient compared to using Webhooks.

definition: Software that provides common services and capabilities to applications outside of what's offered by the operating system.
example: We added authentication middleware to protect the API routes.

definition: A software design pattern for achieving concurrency of execution in a computer program.
example: Using a thread pool prevents the overhead of creating a new thread for every task.

definition: A form of automatic memory management. The garbage collector attempts to reclaim memory which was allocated by the program, but is no longer referenced.
example: In Java, garbage collection handles memory deallocation automatically, unlike in C++.

definition: A type of resource leak that occurs when a computer program incorrectly manages memory allocations in a way that memory which is no longer needed is not released.
example: A memory leak in the long-running process caused the server to run out of RAM.

definition: An anomaly where a program, while writing data to a buffer, overruns the buffer's boundary and overwrites adjacent memory locations.
example: Hackers exploited a buffer overflow vulnerability to execute arbitrary code.

definition: A computer program that runs as a background process, rather than being under the direct control of an interactive user.
example: The web server runs as a daemon, listening for incoming connections in the background.

definition: The central part of an operating system. It manages the operations of the computer and the hardware.
example: The kernel handles communication between the software and the hardware components.

definition: Computer software, firmware or hardware that creates and runs virtual machines.
example: The hypervisor allocates resources from the physical host to the virtual machines.

definition: A form of operating system virtualization, through which applications are run in isolated user spaces called containers.
example: Containerization allows us to run the application consistently across different environments.

definition: A type of compiler that takes the source code of a program written in a programming language as its input and produces the equivalent source code in the same or a different programming language.
example: We use a transpiler to convert modern JavaScript code into a version compatible with older browsers.

definition: A software design pattern that restricts the instantiation of a class to one "single" instance.
example: The database connection manager is implemented using the singleton pattern to ensure only one connection pool exists.
